item.content:encoded:
Its a new month, you know what that means. A monthly game of … how do I say this month in Japanese. This time, I figured since April was “#”-gatsu, May too would be 05-gatsu. I’m curious, why are all the Japanese months denoted as Number-Gatsu versus latin/english where the months (not including the -embers) are named after the Roman gods?

æ—§æš¦ ãã‚…ã†ã‚Œã

The ãã‚…ã†ã‚Œã was used between 1868-1912. It’s denoted as a ‘lunar’ calendar.

item.title: 16 April 2023
item.dc:creator: Ahiã•ã‚“
item.description: Holy shit how do I say April in Japanese. Did Duolingo fail me. Or did I fail myself. Kanji Learned Today
item.content:encoded:
Holy shit how do I say April in Japanese. Did Duolingo fail me. Or did I fail myself.

Research + Answer

ï¼”æœˆ

ã—ãŒã¤

I should’ve known … å››æœˆã¯å›ã®å˜˜ ENG speakers look that up for a pleasant surprise. CW: early 2010s middle school trauma.

ã—ãŒã¤

April is the start month for schools. There’s also a terminology ï¼”æœˆç—…, which is the euphoria experienced by college students or workplace recruits at the beginning of school or work. (Jisho 2023) Is this like the ENG terminology for “Senioritis” or statement “New [School] Year, New Me”
